Inspired by Nesterov's Accelerated Gradient (NAG), we propose a momentum-based algorithm, ARS-OPT, which proactively estimates the gradient with respect to a future ray direction inferred from accumulated momentum. We provide a theoretical analysis of its convergence behavior, showing that ARS-OPT enables more accurate directional updates and achieves faster, more stable optimization. To further accelerate convergence, we incorporate surrogate-model priors into ARS-OPT's gradient estimation, resulting in PARS-OPT with enhanced performance. The superiority of our approach is supported by theoretical guarantees under standard assumptions. Extensive experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that our method surpasses 13 state-of-the-art approaches in query efficiency.

AI.tldr: Proposes ARS-OPT, a momentum-based algorithm for hard-label black-box adversarial attacks that optimizes ray direction search using Nesterov acceleration, with theoretical convergence guarantees and superior query efficiency.
AI.motivation: Hard-label black-box adversarial attacks face prohibitive query complexity as they only have access to top-1 predicted labels, making practical deployment challenging. Existing methods need more efficient optimization approaches.
AI.method: Proposes ARS-OPT, a momentum-based algorithm inspired by Nesterov's Accelerated Gradient that proactively estimates gradient with respect to future ray direction inferred from accumulated momentum. Also introduces PARS-OPT which incorporates surrogate-model priors into gradient estimation for enhanced performance.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows ARS-OPT enables more accurate directional updates and achieves faster, more stable optimization. Extensive experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 demonstrate the method surpasses 13 state-of-the-art approaches in query efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The proposed momentum-based approach with Nesterov acceleration and surrogate-model priors provides an effective solution to the query efficiency problem in hard-label black-box adversarial attacks, with both theoretical guarantees and empirical superiority.

title: Does the Data Processing Inequality Reflect Practice? On the Utility of Low-Level Tasks
summary: The data processing inequality is an information-theoretic principle stating that the information content of a signal cannot be increased by processing the observations. In particular, it suggests that there is no benefit in enhancing the signal or encoding it before addressing a classification problem. This assertion can be proven to be true for the case of the optimal Bayes classifier. However, in practice, it is common to perform "low-level" tasks before "high-level" downstream tasks despite the overwhelming capabilities of modern deep neural networks. In this paper, we aim to understand when and why low-level processing can be beneficial for classification. We present a comprehensive theoretical study of a binary classification setup, where we consider a classifier that is tightly connected to the optimal Bayes classifier and converges to it as the number of training samples increases. We prove that for any finite number of training samples, there exists a pre-classification processing that improves the classification accuracy. We also explore the effect of class separation, training set size, and class balance on the relative gain from this procedure. We support our theory with an empirical investigation of the theoretical setup. Finally, we conduct an empirical study where we investigate the effect of denoising and encoding on the performance of practical deep classifiers on benchmark datasets. Specifically, we vary the size and class distribution of the training set, and the noise level, and demonstrate trends that are consistent with our theoretical results.

AI.tldr: The paper challenges the data processing inequality by showing that pre-classification processing can improve classification accuracy for finite training samples, despite the principle suggesting no benefit.
AI.motivation: To understand why low-level processing (like signal enhancement or encoding) is commonly used before classification tasks in practice, despite the data processing inequality suggesting it shouldn't help, and despite modern neural networks' capabilities.
AI.method: Theoretical study of binary classification with a classifier connected to optimal Bayes classifier; empirical investigation of theoretical setup; and practical experiments with deep classifiers on benchmark datasets using denoising and encoding, varying training size, class distribution, and noise levels.
AI.result: Proved that for any finite number of training samples, there exists pre-classification processing that improves classification accuracy; explored effects of class separation, training set size, and class balance; empirical results support theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: Pre-classification processing can be beneficial for classification with finite training data, challenging the strict interpretation of the data processing inequality in practical scenarios with limited samples.
